title: Lesson 11: Cross Products and Linear Transformations
lesson_title: Cross products in the light of linear transformations
objectives: Understand the determinant formula for cross products

cards.front: How do you compute the 3D cross product using a determinant?
cards.back:
v × w = det([î  v₁  w₁])
              ([ĵ  v₂  w₂])
              ([k̂  v₃  w₃])

Expand along the first column with basis vectors î, ĵ, k̂.

cards.front: What is the formula for v × w in terms of components?
cards.back:
v × w = î(v₂w₃ - v₃w₂) + ĵ(v₃w₁ - v₁w₃) + k̂(v₁w₂ - v₂w₁)

Or as a vector:
[v₂w₃ - v₃w₂]
[v₃w₁ - v₁w₃]
[v₁w₂ - v₂w₁]

cards.front: How does duality explain the cross product?
cards.back:
Treating det([u, v, w]) as a linear function of u (with v, w fixed), there exists a dual vector p such that:

p · u = det([u, v, w])

This dual vector p is exactly v × w.

cards.front: Why does the determinant formula give a vector perpendicular to both inputs?
cards.back:
The dual vector (cross product) must give zero when dotted with v or w (since det is zero when two columns are identical).

Zero dot product means perpendicular.
